Maiden Speech in Parliament on 18th July 2024
Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.
It’s a great pleasure to follow the Honourable Member for Wetherby and Easingwold and the excellent maiden speeches from my Honourable friends for Ealing Southall and Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme.
It gives me great delight to address this House as the new Member of Parliament for Kensington & Bayswater.
I won’t say the last seven weeks have been easy.
I know many honourable members are still catching up on their sleep after the campaign trail, but having our twins born the first week of the General Election campaign took things to another level.
If timing is everything in politics, then this is certainly not a combination I would recommend anyone repeating – even if they will have a great story to tell when they are older.
I do want to take a moment to thank the team at Queen Charlotte’s and across the Imperial College NHS Trust for their incredible care.
Our NHS staff deserve our utmost respect and support – and I hope in the future St Mary’s, Hammersmith and Charing Cross hospitals will finally get what they need to become the first class premises that patients and staff deserve, including delivering on the plans for a brand new St Mary’s hospital.
I want to pay tribute to my two predecessors in this new constituency.
Felicity Buchan worked hard for the residents of Kensington in the past five years, and I want to particularly commend her work on the Homes for Ukraine programme.
There are some issues central to our national and international security that transcend party politics – and supporting the struggle for a free Ukraine is one of them and I’m grateful for her work on this issue.
Kensington & Bayswater is home to the Ukrainian Cultural Centre, the Ukraine Embassy and a substantial Ukrainian population – and having personally worked to support democracy and anti-corruption efforts in Ukraine for many years – I will make sure our Ukrainian community continues to have a strong advocate in Parliament.
I was also fortunate enough to inherit part of Dame Karen Buck’s former constituency of Westminster North – and under previous boundaries, Karen represented North Kensington for many years.
I know from experience that tens of thousands of residents have been directly assisted by Karen and her team with expertise and empathy.
And I hope I can emulate even a small part of her unwavering focus on tackling poverty and our housing crisis – whether it is holding our social housing landlords to account, providing protection for private renters and abolishing section 21 no-fault evictions, or finally ending the outdated feudal leasehold system.
Karen did a monumental amount of work to advance these causes and I’m sure will be delighted with their inclusion in the King’s Speech.
She has always exemplified public service over self-interest and I will do my best to try and live up to her legacy – and I know how grateful we all are for her 27 years of service in this House.
Kensington & Bayswater is an incredible part of London as many of you will already know – with amazing community organisations, businesses, entrepreneurs, charities, heritage, music, parks, schools and so much going for it – but also a deep inequality that has widened in recent years.
There is now a gulf of 19 years between the life expectancy of a woman born in Notting Dale in North Kensington compared with Holland Park – only a third of a mile away from each other – a gap that has increased by 5 years in the last decade alone.
Over 6000 children are living in poverty, and over 3000 families are on a growing housing waiting list.
So while we are rightly proud of our contribution to the nation’s economy in terms of growth, talent and innovation in so many different industries.
And we celebrate the tourists who come to visit our museums, Portobello Road and our parks – we must also tackle the underlying causes of that inequality, from housing to education and employment opportunities.
Because I know from the thousands of people I’ve met across our constituency that far too many feel like government is not working for them.
They see too many politicians putting political party before country, self-interest before community.
And I know that trust in government – and politicians – has plummeted in this country as a result.
But it doesn’t have to be this way. I’ve spent my career working to make democracy work better in dozens of countries around the world by supporting reformers in government to work with civil society to be more transparent, more inclusive and more accountable – and to deliver for people on the priorities they care about.
In Kensington & Bayswater that means for example getting a grip on the dirty money in luxury property that still stains our community.
Despite recent progress in legislation and the leadership that Baroness Hodge and others have shown in this House, we still have one of the highest numbers of anonymously owned properties registered in tax havens in our constituency – with loopholes allowing autocrats and kleptocats to continue shielding their ownership.
Many of those properties sit empty – hurting our local businesses, our schools and hollowing out our sense of a shared community.
So I am determined to build on our Kensington Against Dirty Money campaign, and continue advocating for London to end its reputation as the dirty money capital of the world, and instead become the anti-corruption capital of the world.
There is no worse example of what happens when government stops listening to people, and transparency and accountability is discarded, than what happened at Grenfell Tower over seven years ago.
72 people lost their lives in an entirely preventable tragedy – and yet we still do not have Truth, Justice and Change for the bereaved, survivors and affected community.
These are people whose lives were changed forever on the 14th June 2017, and who have had to wait far too long for justice, and for those responsible to be held to account.
In the coming weeks the second phase of the Public Inquiry will report and I know honourable members here will join me in looking to those recommendations to ensure that a tragedy like Grenfell can never happen again.
I warmly welcome the inclusion of the duty of candour law for public servants in the King’s Speech and applaud the effective campaigning from those affected by Grenfell, Hillsborough, Infected Blood, Windrush and others who have suffered from the unacceptable defensive culture across too much of the public sector.
And I hope we can look at further measures to ensure robust oversight of the implementation of recommendations from these inquiries.
Mr Deputy Speaker, Kensington & Bayswater is a special place, making a huge contribution to our national life in so many ways, and my hope is working with this Labour government we become a fairer place too, building on our strengths and addressing the inequalities that hold us back.
It won’t be easy and it won’t happen overnight. As a QPR fan I’ve learnt over many years to be realistic.
But we have to grasp this opportunity, to restore faith and trust in government and our democracy and to provide hope once again for a brighter future.
I thank you, Mr. Deputy Speaker, for giving me the opportunity to make my maiden speech today.

As the MP for Kensington and Bayswater, I and my constituency staff correspond with constituents to answer policy enquiries, take up casework, and ask for views on local and national issues.
As the holder of that data, I am the Data Controller. By virtue of my work as a Member of Parliament, my office staff will also have access to limited data in order to ensure the smooth running of my office. This policy will therefore reference “we”, to include me as MP, as well as my office staff.
This document explains how I collect and use personal data arising from this correspondence, the legal basis for doing so, and explains your rights in relation to your personal data.
Data collection and use
Policy enquiries and casework (where a constituent seeks my support on a matter that affects them personally) bring with them personal data provided by or on behalf of the constituent. This personal data may include, but is not limited to: name, address, email address, telephone number.
It may also include ‘Special Category’ data which is usually considered more private and sensitive. Special Category data relates to a person’s racial or ethnic origin; political opinions; religious or philosophical beliefs; trade union membership; genetic data; biometric data (where used for identification purposes); health; sex life; sexual orientation.
We will only collect and use personal data for the specific purpose for which it has been provided. We will only use Special Category data where we have both a legal basis to do so, as well as an additional condition to process.
We will not transfer your data beyond the EEA unless we have implemented appropriate safeguards, which are likely to be Standard Contractual Clauses, or where an “adequacy decision” has been granted by the appropriate authorities.
Who do I share your personal information with?
When processing your correspondence, we will only share your information with a third-party organisation where it is necessary and reasonable to do so.
Third-parties, include but are not limited to: government departments, local authorities, public bodies, health trusts, regulators, system providers (with appropriate agreements or contracts in place).
We will only share as much information as is necessary to take your enquiry forward.
We will never share or sell your personal data to other organisations for direct marketing purposes.
Lawful basis for processing
Personal data is processed for one or more of the following lawful bases:
Retention of personal data
We will only retain your personal information for as long as it is necessary to fulfil the purposes described when your personal data was originally collected. However, to provide the best service and representation for constituents, it may be necessary to revisit closed casework and policy enquiries. Closed policy enquiries will be securely and permanently deleted at the end of the Parliamentary session in which they were made. We may retain information about closed casework to be able to give you full support, should you contact us again for help. If you wish to exercise your rights to erasure, you are welcome to do so. Please see the ‘Your rights’ section for more information.
Security of your Data
We are committed to processing and retaining data within established technological and physical controls in a transparent manner, as well as promoting and safeguarding the information rights of data subjects.
Our procedures ensure that technological and physical controls are in place that guarantee the privacy of data subjects, the security of data held on technological systems is processed according to an established lawful processing condition. Any such procedures will be reviewed as necessary and updated to ensure their effectiveness in line with advances in technology.
Links to other websites
Correspondence from my office may provide links to other websites. We are not responsible for the content or privacy practices of these websites.

As your MP for Kensington and Bayswater, I will always fight for cleaner air for our children
Clean air helps to increase children’s life expectancy, reduces hospital admissions for asthma and serious lung conditions, and enables people to lead longer, healthier lives.
That’s why I’ve been meeting with national and local organisations who are championing cleaner air for residents in Kensington and Bayswater and why I continue to push Kensington & Chelsea Council to take more measures to encourage active travel in our borough.
For too long, lung health has been sidelined, under-treated and under-resourced. Lung conditions affect 1 in 5 people in the UK, and in 2020/2021, there were over 10,000 respiratory-related emergency hospital admissions in North West London, a major cause of winter pressures on our health service.
I recently met with the national charity Asthma + Lung UK to address how poor lung health affects residents of Kensington and Bayswater. We discussed the urgent need for change to remove health inequalities and improve lung health for all.
I recently met with Clean Air Bayswater, a group of local residents taking action to improve the air quality in Bayswater. Clean Air Bayswater brings together local schools, residents, and businesses to ensure that everyone in our community understands the importance of breathing clean air and the role we all play in improving it.
As your MP for Kensington & Bayswater, I will continue championing national and local projects to make our community a safer, healthier place to live.

I’m calling on The Crown Estate to urgently open Kensington Palace Gardens to pedestrians and cyclists, after their decision to close the road.
The Crown Estate owns the road, which provides a crucial, safe connection between Notting Hill Gate and Kensington High Street for thousands of pedestrians and cyclists every day.
In a letter to the Crown Estate, I wrote: “Kensington Palace Gardens is a crucial north-south thoroughfare for local residents and visitors.
“The Borough of Kensington and Chelsea ranks bottom for healthy and safe streets in Inner London, making the road even more important for pedestrians and cyclists.
“Your decision will impact thousands of people a day, and sets a dangerous precedent of decisions being taken without consultation with your neighbours and the local community who will rightly view this as a selfish and spiteful act.”
The last thing we need with a Council and MP with a track record of blocking any initiatives to make our streets safer is one of the few safe roads for pedestrians and cyclists to be closed.
Sign my petition today and ask The Crown Estate to think again, and reopen the road.

It was a privilege to visit the hospital on Tuesday, alongside the Shadow Secretary of State for Health Wes Streeting, to announce this important news for patients and staff across Kensington & Bayswater.
Since becoming your Labour candidate for Kensington and Bayswater, I have campaigned tirelessly for St Mary’s to be saved – and with your help, we have succeeded!
St Mary’s was one of 40 new hospitals that Boris Johnson and the Conservative MP for Kensington promised to build in their 2019 General Election campaign. However, the Tories shamefully removed St Mary’s from their 2030 New Hospital Programme last May, despite the terrible condition of the estate. Their claim that a few million pounds of planning money is a substitute for the £2.2 billion needed for a new hospital is disingenuous and insulting to staff and patients.
The three local hospitals in the Imperial College Healthcare Trust —St Mary’s, Hammersmith, and Charing Cross—have the largest major risk repair backlog of any NHS estate in the country. The Conservative government’s decision to break its promise to our hospitals was described by the CEO as “hugely damaging to the health and healthcare of hundreds of thousands of people.”
I am delighted that Labour will reverse this decision if we win on 4th July.
I also want to take this opportunity to thank everyone who signed my petition to rebuild our local hospitals and took part in our local ‘Save Our NHS’ campaign I launched last year.
There is now a clear choice for our community at the election. If you want a new St Mary’s, lower waiting lists, more mental health workers, and NHS dentistry back on its feet, then vote Labour on July 4th.
Together, with a Labour government, we can deliver the change our NHS desperately needs.

The New Hospital Programme has today confirmed a £50 million investment over the next three years to allow Imperial College Healthcare to continue to the detailed design and planning phase for its St Mary’s Hospital redevelopment in Paddington.
This phase of work is intended to conclude with planning consent for a new hospital within a redeveloped life sciences campus in 2027/28. A first tranche of £19.4 million has been released from what is anticipated to be a total of around £50 million to complete this phase.
Joe Powell, the MP for Kensington and Bayswater said:
“Today’s news of the biggest ever government investment in the new St Mary’s project is a massive vote of confidence for the project. Residents across North and West London are desperate for this project to start as soon as possible and I agree.
“The £50m investment over the next three years will allow planning and development work to be accelerated, and explore maximising the Paddington Basin site so we can secure financing to bring forward construction as soon as possible.
“This funding allows us to take that step and get the project back on track after the Conservative government removed it from the national 2030 New Hospital Programme in May 2023.”

Only Labour can be trusted with our NHS after 14 years of Tory neglect
With waiting lists now at 7.5 million people, I am outraged that the government has broken its election promise to our community to rebuild and repair St Mary’s, Hammersmith, and Charing Cross hospitals by 2030.
The Conservative government’s decision to break its promise to our hospital was described by Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust as “hugely damaging to the health and healthcare of hundreds of thousands of people.”
That’s why I wrote a joint letter to the Health Secretary in November, the seventh in just 13 years under the Tories, urging the government to reinstate their broken pledge to save our local hospitals.
The longer the Tories are in power the longer patients in Kensington and Bayswater will wait.
Labour has a plan to slash the NHS waiting list with 40, 000 new appointments a year.
Labour has turned the NHS around before. And we’ll do it again.

Last Thursday, this community sent a loud and clear message that after 14 long years of Conservative government, it’s time for change.
I’m proud of the positive campaign we ran, and I want to thank the people of Kensington & Bayswater for putting your trust in me. Being the MP for Kensington & Bayswater is the greatest honour of my life.
The hard work starts now.
I know from the thousands of people I’ve met on the doorstep that for too many in our community, government is not working for them.
From the millions on NHS waiting lists, to households struggling to make ends meet, to the housing crisis for renters, social tenants, and homeowners, and to the bereaved, survivors, and affected community still waiting for justice seven years after the Grenfell fire tragedy, it is clear that trust in government—and politicians—is at rock bottom in this country as a result.
That’s why I chose to stand to represent this community. As your MP, I will continue fighting to tackle corruption, fix the housing crisis and create more opportunities for our young people. Under Labour, we will start the work to build a new St Mary’s Hospital and get the NHS back on its feet again, delivering for patients in Kensington and Bayswater.
As we near the publication of the Phase 2 Report on the Grenfell in September, I will continue advocating for truth, justice, and change.
None of this will be easy or indeed happen overnight, but I believe with Keir Starmer as Prime Minister and the Labour Party in government, change is coming.
Regardless of whether you voted for me or not, I will work hard to earn your trust and deliver for our community.
P.S. I am in the process of setting up my new office. If you are a constituent with a casework query, please get in touch with my office [email protected].

Tackling corruption and inequality in the heart of Kensington
Taking on corruption and tax dodging will always be at the core of my mission. Dirty money erodes our democracy, increases inequality, and means we have fewer public resources for health, education and other public services.
I led a ‘kleptocracy tour’ with Margaret Hodge MP, visiting luxury Kensington homes bought by foreign leaders who are subject to sanctions. These properties are linked to the Russian foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, and the Azerbaijani president, Ilham Aliyev, in gated communities in Kensington.
For too long, we have allowed luxury properties to be bought up by autocrats, oligarchs and their families who are looting their own countries and stashing that wealth in places like this. This undermines those pushing for democracy in places like Russia and Azerbaijan, but it also undermines our local communities which is why I launched Kensington Against Dirty Money in 2022.
Dirty money also drives obscene levels of inequality in our community. This borough has 4 out of the 10 most expensive streets in England, and we also have two of the poorest neighbourhoods in London.
The life expectancy gap for women in those neighbourhoods is now 11.9 years – the largest increase in inequality in the past decade in the whole country.
At the same time, we have a housing crisis with more than 3,000 households waiting for a home and 2,100 in temporary accommodation. We have the highest number of empty homes in the country.
This can’t go on.
I know from campaigning across this constituency as a parliamentary candidate that people want change. It’s bad for our housing crisis, bad for our schools with half-empty classrooms, and it’s bad for local businesses. It hollows out the community.

I’m calling on The Crown Estate to urgently reopen Kensington Palace Gardens to pedestrians and cyclists after they decided to close the road.
The Crown Estate owns the road, which provides a crucial, safe connection between Notting Hill Gate and Kensington High Street for thousands of pedestrians and cyclists every day.
Kensington & Chelsea is already ranked the worst inner London borough for active travel by the Healthy Streets coalition. The last thing we need with a Council and MP with a track record of blocking any initiatives to make our streets safer is one of the few safe roads for pedestrians and cyclists to be closed.
Sign my petition today and ask The Crown Estate to think again, and reopen the road.

The case for a new St Mary’s Hospital has never been stronger, as is the need for a floor-by-floor refurbishment of Hammersmith and Charing Cross hospitals.
Patients and staff have been let down for years, and I was appalled that the entire Imperial College NHS Trust was relegated from the list of projects to be completed by 2030 by the previous Conservative government. The money to build a new St Mary’s hospital was simply never allocated, giving people false hope and rightly creating distrust in the entire New Hospital Programme.
I welcome the Government’s review of the New Hospital Programme. It is vital we get clarity on the funding for these three local hospitals so that plans can advance.
As the new MP for Kensington and Bayswater, I will continue working closely with the Imperial Trust team, the Health Secretary, and surrounding MPs to secure the best possible outcomes for our community, including a plan to get our local hospitals what they need as soon as possible.
Joe Powell is an anti-corruption champion who has spent his life campaigning for social justice and democracy in West London, Britain and around the world, delivering real results.
Before becoming an MP, he was Deputy CEO of the Open Government Partnership, an organisation founded by Barack Obama to support democracy globally, including in Britain where Joe ran successful campaigns to force big oil, gas and mining companies to open up their books and pay their taxes.
Joe is an active and winning campaigner for a fairer Kensington. In 2022, he founded the Kensington Against Dirty Money campaign that has pushed national and local governments to take action on inequality by reducing corrupt wealth in our borough, going after empty homes, and investing more in social housing.
Joe lives in Ladbroke Grove, and grew up in Queen’s Park. He is a proud member of our community. His son and twins were born at Queen Charlotte’s Hospital and he’s a lifelong QPR fan.
Squeezed wages, runaway food inflation, soaring rents and mortgages, and Tory tax rises have left British households suffering.
Labour has extended the windfall tax on oil and gas company profits to provide added support for households and business.
The Tories broke their promise to rebuild or upgrade St Mary’s Paddington, Hammersmith and Charing Cross hospitals by 2030. Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust says this decision will be “hugely damaging for the health and healthcare of hundreds of thousands of people”.
Under a Labour government, I will continue to make the case for our local hospitals.
Too many of our communities suffer from anti-social behaviour and crime made worse by over a decade of cuts, including a cut of 75% to London’s Police and Community Support Officers.
I will continue to campaign to keep Notting Hill Police Station in public hands, and Labour will prevent crime by putting 13,000 extra neighbourhood police and PCSOs on Britain’s streets.
Rents and mortgages are through the roof, and we have a huge shortage of social housing. Labour will build 1.5 million new homes, and I will continue to campaign against dirty money in luxury property, for leasehold reform and for Truth, Justice and Change for Grenfell bereaved and survivors.
As your MP I am always here to listen, support and amplify the campaign for those responsible to be held accountable, and for changes to be made to ensure this never happens again.
I co-founded Kensington Against Dirty Money because we are at the epicentre of Britain’s addiction to corrupt wealth, much of it stashed in luxury property in our borough.
Taking on corruption and tax dodging is at the core of my mission, because it erodes our democracy, increases inequality, and means we have less public resources for health, education and other public services.
The climate emergency is the greatest threat to humankind. Its effects can be felt right here in our community, in the form of flooding and extreme temperatures. Air pollution blights many of our neighbourhoods, harming our children. Labour will insulate millions of homes, and make Britain a clean energy superpower.
Locally, I am supporting schemes to reduce air pollution, promoting community energy projects and working with local groups and the Council to encourage more active travel like cycling and walking.

Labour’s Sadiq Khan wins historic third term as London Mayor taking West Central in the Mayoral and Assembly elections for the first time
The result shows only Labour can beat the Conservatives at the General Election this year.
Sadiq Khan made history on 2nd May by winning a third term with a notable swing towards Labour. The final results saw Sadiq Khan win 1,088,225 votes to the Conservative’s 811,518.
Labour made key gains in the West Central London Assembly seat, securing over 10,000 votes more than the Conservative candidate. The constituency, which covers the boroughs of Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea (RBKC) and Westminster, decisively backed Labour in the mayoral and London Assembly vote. This is the first time Labour has won in West Central.
A historic third term for Sadiq Khan in City Hall means Labour can continue delivering for our great city and the residents of Kensington and Bayswater – from building more affordable homes to more police on our streets and keeping our children healthy with free school meals and tougher action on air quality.
Labour takes West Central in the London Assembly
Labour won the West Central London Assembly seat for the first time, electing James Small-Edwards as the first-ever Labour London Assembly member with a majority of 4,000 votes.
James will be a brilliant Assembly Member and advocate for our area, bringing much-needed positive change to residents. In his acceptance speech, James emphasised that continuing support for the cost of living crisis will be one of his key priorities, alongside more affordable housing and action on climate change.
Norland ward by-election
Labour also made huge inroads in the Norland ward RBKC council by-election, taking second place with 29% of the vote. This election saw a 9% increase in the Party’s vote share since 2022 and a swing from Conservative to Labour.

It was a privilege to visit QPR in the Community Trust in North Kensington to see the incredible work they do to support children in our community.
Being born in a certain area should never define your health, opportunities and aspirations.
The Trust’s mission is to create a stronger, healthier, more active community where everyone can thrive, addressing local needs and making a difference to young people in our communities.
Established in 1994 and obtaining charitable status in 2009, the Trust – driven by local needs and with the support of partners, funders and stakeholders – work across seven London boroughs to provide opportunities based on the main objectives of health, education, social inclusion and participation.
Tackling national issues at a local level, every year the Trust engage with 23,000 participants with a focus on:
- Positive physical and mental health
- Supporting young people to reach their full potential

Therefore I join Imperial College NHS Trust in welcoming the Government’s review of the New Hospital Programme. It is vital we get clarity on the funding for these three local hospitals so that plans can advance.

Many residents have contacted me about the terrible situation in Gaza and Israel.
I support an immediate ceasefire, a massive increase in aid, the release of hostages and accountability for implementing the ICJ provisional recommendations. I want to see the path to a two-state solution revived with a fully recognised Palestinian state achieved as soon as possible, not just at the end of a lengthy process. This commitment was reinforced in the Labour Party manifesto which states “Palestinian statehood is an inalienable right of the Palestinian people. It is not in the gift of any neighbour and it is also essential to the long-term security of Israel.” However challenging it may be, it is the UK’s moral duty to work with our international partners to achieve a two-state solution and sustainable peace in the region.
I’ve worked my entire career in international development, open government and anti-corruption – so I care deeply about human rights and tackling poverty. It’s clear to me that the suffering of the innocent people of Gaza is an affront to those values, as are the long-standing indictments of corruption against Benjamin Netanyahu. It’s also why we need change so desperately in this country and in our area. If we want to tackle the housing crisis, make work pay, implement real climate change policies, and rebuild our NHS then we need a Labour government and a Labour MP in Kensington & Bayswater. Any other vote risks five more years of Conservative government and five more years of a Tory MP for our community.

Leaseholders in Kensington & Bayswater have been let down by the Tories.
It’s time for change.
For far too many leaseholders, the reality of home ownership falls woefully short of the dream they were promised.
Labour will act where the Conservatives have failed and finally bring the feudal leasehold system to an end.
We will enact the package of Law Commission proposals on leasehold enfranchisement, right to manage and commonhold.
We will take further steps to ban new leasehold flats and ensure commonhold is the default tenure. We will tackle unregulated and unaffordable ground rent charges.
Labour act to bring the injustice of ‘fleecehold’ private housing estates and unfair maintenance costs to an end.
It was brilliant to welcome Matthew Pennycook to Kensington and Bayswater to discuss Labour’s plans for leasehold reform.
As your MP for Kensington and Bayswater, I’ll do everything I can to fight for leaseholders

It was a privilege to visit North Kensington Community Energy with Labour’s Shadow Secretary of State of Climate Change and Net Zero, Ed Miliband MP, to see the community-owned solar project in action at Westway Sports Centre.
North Kensington Community Energy was born in 2018 with the aim of making Kensington & Chelsea a greener and fairer borough by installing community-owned solar panels.
Under a Labour government, our Local Power Plan will support community-owned projects like this around the country to lower bills, create jobs, and tackle climate change.
Labour’s Green Prosperity Plan
To address the climate crisis, the Labour Party has committed to a Green Prosperity Plan. Labour has committed to achieving the substantial majority of our emissions by 2020, making climate justice a priority, and taking action to accelerate the benefits of nature restoration and recovery.
Labour’s mission is to make the UK a clean energy superpower. It is a plan that will make energy cheap and secure so that the British public never again faces spiralling bills, boost jobs and investment in every region and nation of the country, and grow our economy from the bottom up and middle out.
Powered by our Green Prosperity Plan, a Labour government will help Britain lead the world in cheaper, cleaner power and industry:
1. Cutting energy bills for good – taking up to £1,400 off the annual household bill and £53 billion off energy bills
2. Establish GB Energy – a new home-grown, publicly-owned champion in clean energy generation – to build jobs and supply chains here at home
3. Upgrade millions of homes with our Warm Homes Plan, so that families have cheaper energy bills permanently, with warm, future-proofed homes
4. Set up the National Wealth Fund, which will create good, well-paying jobs by investing alongside the private sector in gigafactories, clean steel plants, renewable-ready ports, green hydrogen and energy storage.
5. Act fast to lead the worst with clean and cheap power by 2030, backing up the builders, not the blockers so Britain gets the cheap, clean power we need
